My experience is more than a few years old, but I would recommend taking it. I imagine my siblings, who also took FTC, would recommend the same.

It is the full year of calculus in 5 weeks, it is a lot of work. I always made sure to take off Friday evening, but for the most part the rest of my time was working on homework or being in class.

There are huge benefits.

* Calculus is required for everyone and was (is?) a 5 day per week course. I think it was mostly taught in the morning, but I remember it always being a pain for my friends to fit in their schedule.
* You will be free to get a jump start on other Math classes - I ended up taking differential equations and discrete & combinatorial algebra throughout my freshman year. My freshman schedule had so many more interesting classes than did my non-FTC friends.
* It had the benefits of opening up more classes because of pre-reqs. I graduated with a double major*, were I not on scholarship (and interested in taking more electives), I could have easily graduated 2 terms early without much effort (I actually had to choose to not take a humanities course, so that I wouldn't accidentally graduate).
* It doubled as an intensive course in Maple (mathematics software, not sure if Maple is still the program of choice).
* You make friends and get to know the campus before everyone else.
* war stories?

If they have accepted you and think you can do it, I recommend going for it.

\* Edit/Caveat: My double major was CS and Math, so there was a fair amount of overlap already (you couldn't minor in Math if you were getting a CS major because it was already built into the CS major requirements). This may not be reproducible with all combinations of double majors.
